templates.name: Independence Hall
templates.description: Independence Hall is where the Second Continental Congress met and where the Declaration of Independence was adopted in 1776. It is one of the most iconic locations associated with the founding of the United States.

templates.name: Tun Tavern
templates.description: Tun Tavern is often considered the birthplace of the United States Marine Corps. It's where the first official Marine recruiting station was established in 1775.

templates.name: Plymouth Rock
templates.description: Although not a city, Plymouth Rock is a symbol of the Pilgrims' arrival in 1620 and the beginning of European settlement in New England.

templates.name: Concord's N Bridge
templates.description: Site of the "Shot Heard 'Round the World," marking the beginning of the American Revolution.

templates.name: Bunker Hill
templates.description: The Battle of Bunker Hill, a key early battle in the American Revolution.

templates.name: Old North Church
templates.description: Known for the signal lanterns that Paul Revere used to warn of the British advance in 1775.

templates.name: Ford's Theatre
templates.description: The location where President Abraham Lincoln was assassinated by John Wilkes Booth in 1865.

templates.name: Lexington Green
templates.description: The first skirmish between British forces and American colonists occurred here in 1775.

templates.name: Harper's Ferry
templates.description: The site of John Brown's raid in 1859, an event that played a role in the lead-up to the Civil War.

templates.name: Fort Sumter
templates.description: The location of the first shots fired in the American Civil War in 1861.

templates.name: Mount Rushmore
templates.description: The iconic sculpture featuring the faces of four U.S. Presidents - George Washington, Thomas Jefferson, Theodore Roosevelt, and Abraham Lincoln.

templates.name: Seneca Falls
templates.description: Site of the 1848 Women's Rights Convention, a pivotal event in the women's suffrage movement.

templates.name: Fort McHenry
templates.description: During the War of 1812, this fort played a significant role and inspired the writing of the national anthem, "The Star-Spangled Banner."
